In the blockchain, the reasonable security assumption is adopted, where the fraction of the credit value held by malicious blockchain nodes is assumed to be less than 1/3131/3. In the following, we analyze the finality, consistency, and efficiency of our PF-PoFL system, as well as security analysis in defending against adversaries defined in Sect. III-B.

  • •

    Finality and consistency. According to [18, 30], under the above majority honest assumption, our PF-PoFL system is resilient up to 1/3131/3 credit values held by malicious or Byzantine nodes, and all honest nodes can reach an agreement on the same block with overwhelming probability. It ensures the finality and consistency of the blockchain, as well as the prevention of blockchain forks and double-spending threats.

  • •

    Consensus efficiency. Under the strong synchrony assumption (i.e., messages sent by most honest nodes can be received by most other honest nodes within a known time bound), the BBA* protocol is proved to reach agreement within one stage, thereby ensuring the high efficiency of consensus protocol in common situations.

  • •

    Defense of spoofing attack. In the model ranking smart contract, a model transaction will not be included in the candidate block by honest validators if it is published within the testing phase of the task. Hence, trainers do not have incentives to cheat by training a perfect model on the test data. Besides, as only the hashes of trained FL models are released in federated mining process, adversaries cannot plagiarize the FL models trained by other pools. Besides, the payment delivery to members of the winning pool is executed automatically via the block rewarding smart contract, the refusal-to-pay threat can be avoided. Thereby, PF-PoFL can resist spoofing attacks.

  • •

    Defense of Sybil attack. By introducing the participation fee, trainers/pools have to pay a participation fee before their trained models are ranked, which increases the cost for nodes to carry out Sybil attacks. Besides, as the committee members are randomly formed via VRF based on their credit values, Sybil attacks to the committee selection process can be prevented, as well as ensuring fairness for blockchain nodes. Thereby, PF-PoFL can mitigate Sybil attacks.

  • •

    Defense of the central platform. PF-PoFL offers a fully decentralized solution for the life-cycle process including task outsourcing, model training, model ranking, and reward sharing. In PF-PoFL, as the third-party platform is removed, potential risks it brings including SPoF, collusion, and sensitive information leakage can be avoided.

  • •

    Privacy leakage prevention. According to Theorem 2, PF-PoFL ensures UDP for miners to prevent user-level privacy leakage during federated mining. Besides, as the committee selection is pseudo-random and non-interactive and the committee members are replaced in every stage, adversaries cannot target a committee member until that validator starts participation. Thereby, PF-PoFL also ensures membership unpredictability for validators to prevent from being targeted.

V Dynamic Optimized Pool Structure Formation

In this section, we first analyze the federation utility of each pool, then we present a stable pool formation algorithm based on the federation formation game, followed by the property analysis of the proposed algorithm.

V-A Federation Utility Function

The federation utility of pool ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j} is determined by the accuracy loss of the trained global model and the federation cost. First, we characterize the expected accuracy loss of the global model under federated mining in Sect. IV-D.

1) Non-IID effect. The non-IID data can affect the accuracy of the global model under FL. We adopt the widely used average earth mover's distance (EMD) to measure the heterogeneity of data distribution among diverse miners [31]. In a typical classification problem with Y𝑌Y classes defined over a label space 𝒴={1,⋯,Y}𝒴1⋯𝑌\mathcal{Y}=\{1,\cdots,Y\} and a compact space 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}. Let Prm​(y=k)subscriptPr𝑚𝑦𝑘\mathrm{Pr}_{m}(y=k) denote the proportion of miner m𝑚m's local training samples with label k∈𝒴𝑘𝒴k\in\mathcal{Y}, and Pr​(y=k)Pr𝑦𝑘\mathrm{Pr}(y=k) be the proportion of training samples with label k∈𝒴𝑘𝒴k\in\mathcal{Y} in all miners' training data. Thereby, Pr​(y),∀y∈𝒴Pr𝑦for-all𝑦𝒴\mathrm{Pr}(y),\forall y\in\mathcal{Y} denotes the data distribution for each data sample {𝐱,y}𝐱𝑦\{\mathbf{x},y\} distributed over 𝒳×𝒴𝒳𝒴\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}. The EMD of miner m∈ℳτ𝑚subscriptℳ𝜏m\in\mathcal{M}_{\tau} is computed as

Ξm=∑k=1Y‖Prm​(y=k)−Pr​(y=k)‖.subscriptΞ𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑌normsubscriptPr𝑚𝑦𝑘Pr𝑦𝑘\displaystyle\Xi_{m}=\sum_{k=1}^{Y}{||\mathrm{Pr}_{m}(y=k)-\mathrm{Pr}(y=k)||}. (21)

The average EMD in pool ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j} is computed as the weighted sum of all miners' EMDs, which is expressed as

Ξ¯j=∑m=1|ℑj|sm∑m=1|ℑj|sm​Ξm,subscript¯Ξ𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑗subscript𝑠𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑗subscript𝑠𝑚subscriptΞ𝑚\displaystyle\overline{\Xi}_{j}=\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{|\Im_{j}|}{\frac{s_{m}}{\sum_{m=1}^{|\Im_{j}|}{s_{m}}}}\Xi_{m}, (22)

where smsubscript𝑠𝑚s_{m} is miner m𝑚m's local data size, and |ℑj|subscript𝑗{|\Im_{j}|} is the number of members in pool ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j}.

2) Latency analysis. In a global communication round k𝑘k, the total latency consists of (i) local training latency Dtlksuperscriptsubscript𝐷tl𝑘D_{\mathrm{tl}}^{k} in local model training and (ii) network latency Dnlksuperscriptsubscript𝐷nl𝑘D_{\mathrm{nl}}^{k} for uploading the trained local model and receiving the latest global model using wired/wireless networks. According to [32], we have Dnlk≫Dtlkmuch-greater-thansuperscriptsubscript𝐷nl𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐷tl𝑘D_{\mathrm{nl}}^{k}\gg D_{\mathrm{tl}}^{k}, thereby Dtlksuperscriptsubscript𝐷tl𝑘D_{\mathrm{tl}}^{k} can be negligible. Here, the maximum waiting time (i.e., Djmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑗D_{j}^{\max}) of pool ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j} in a global communication round is defined as

Djmax=β​D¯nl=β​∑m=1|ℑj|D¯nl,m,superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑗𝛽subscript¯𝐷nl𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑗subscript¯𝐷nl𝑚\displaystyle D_{j}^{\max}=\beta\overline{D}_{\mathrm{nl}}=\beta\sum_{m=1}^{|\Im_{j}|}{\overline{D}_{\mathrm{nl},m}}, (23)

where β>0𝛽0\beta>0 is an adjustment factor to control the ratio of participants in a global communication round. D¯nlsubscript¯𝐷nl\overline{D}_{\mathrm{nl}} is the average network latency of all miners in the pool ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j}. D¯nl,msubscript¯𝐷nl𝑚{\overline{D}_{\mathrm{nl},m}} is the expected network latency of miner m∈ℑj𝑚subscript𝑗m\in\Im_{j}.

3) Number of training samples. In a global communication round, the total number of data samples used for model training in pool ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j} is denoted as Sj=∑m=1|ℑj|αm​smsubscript𝑆𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑗subscript𝛼𝑚subscript𝑠𝑚S_{j}=\sum_{m=1}^{|\Im_{j}|}{\alpha_{m}s_{m}}. Here, αm={0,1}subscript𝛼𝑚01\alpha_{m}=\{0,1\} is a binary variable, i.e.,

αm={1,if​D¯nl,m≤Djmax,0,otherwise.subscript𝛼𝑚cases1ifsubscript¯𝐷nl𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑗0otherwise\displaystyle\alpha_{m}=\begin{cases}1,&\mathrm{if}\ {\overline{D}_{\mathrm{nl},m}}\leq D_{j}^{\max},\\ 0,&\mathrm{otherwise}.\end{cases} (24)

It means that only miners with D¯nl,m≤Djmaxsubscript¯𝐷nl𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑗{\overline{D}_{\mathrm{nl},m}}\leq D_{j}^{\max} are admitted to join the model training.

4) Total global communication rounds. The number of global communication rounds of pool ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j} can be computed as Ψj,τglobal=⌊Tτtrain/Djmax⌋superscriptsubscriptΨ𝑗𝜏globalsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝜏trainsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑗\Psi_{j,\tau}^{\mathrm{global}}=\lfloor T_{\tau}^{\mathrm{train}}/D_{j}^{\max}\rfloor. Here, Tτtrainsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝜏trainT_{\tau}^{\mathrm{train}} is the total training time duration (measured by block height) of a FL task, as shown in Fig. 5.

5) Expected accuracy loss. The accuracy loss of the global model after Ψj,τglobalsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝑗𝜏global\Psi_{j,\tau}^{\mathrm{global}} rounds can be measured by the prediction loss between the optimal parameter Θ∗superscriptΘ\Theta^{*} and the parameter Θ​(Ψj,τglobal)ΘsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝑗𝜏global\Theta(\Psi_{j,\tau}^{\mathrm{global}}), i.e., ℒ​(Θ​(Ψj,τglobal))−ℒ​(Θ∗)ℒΘsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝑗𝜏globalℒsuperscriptΘ\mathcal{L}(\Theta(\Psi_{j,\tau}^{\mathrm{global}}))-\mathcal{L}(\Theta^{*}). According to [33, 34], when adopting mini-batch SGD for local training, the expected accuracy loss ΠjsubscriptΠ𝑗\Pi_{j} under non-IID case is bounded by 𝒪​(ℰ​(Ξ¯j)​(1Sj​Ψj,τglobal+1Ψj,τglobal))𝒪ℰsubscript¯Ξ𝑗1subscript𝑆𝑗superscriptsubscriptΨ𝑗𝜏global1superscriptsubscriptΨ𝑗𝜏global\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\mathcal{E}(\overline{\Xi}_{j})\Big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{S_{j}\Psi_{j,\tau}^{\mathrm{global}}}}+\frac{1}{\Psi_{j,\tau}^{\mathrm{global}}}\Big{)}\Big{)}. Here, ℰ​(Ξ¯j)ℰsubscript¯Ξ𝑗\mathcal{E}(\overline{\Xi}_{j}) is the relative accuracy loss function. Obviously, the expected accuracy loss decreases with the increase of the number of global iterations Ψj,τglobalsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝑗𝜏global\Psi_{j,\tau}^{\mathrm{global}} and the number of training samples Sjsubscript𝑆𝑗S_{j}.

Apart from the federated mining strategy, miners can also employ the solo mining strategy, in which the miner m𝑚m chooses to work alone and forms a singleton, i.e., ℑj={m}subscript𝑗𝑚\Im_{j}=\{m\}. Under this case, the expected accuracy loss bound can be approximated as 𝒪​(ℰ​(Ξm)​(1sm​Ψmax,τlocal+1Ψmax,τlocal))𝒪ℰsubscriptΞ𝑚1subscript𝑠𝑚superscriptsubscriptΨ𝜏local1superscriptsubscriptΨ𝜏local\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\mathcal{E}(\Xi_{m})\Big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{s_{m}\Psi_{\max,\tau}^{\mathrm{local}}}}+\frac{1}{\Psi_{\max,\tau}^{\mathrm{local}}}\Big{)}\Big{)}, where Ψmax,τlocalsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝜏local\Psi_{\max,\tau}^{\mathrm{local}} is the maximum number of local epoches in training task τ𝜏\tau to avoid overfitting. To summarize, the explicit form of the expected accuracy loss is expressed as

Πj={ℰ​(Ξ¯j)​(1Sj​Ψj,τglobal+1Ψj,τglobal),if​|ℑj|>1,ℰ​(Ξm)​(1sm​Ψmax,τlocal+1Ψmax,τlocal),if​|ℑj|=1.subscriptΠ𝑗casesℰsubscript¯Ξ𝑗1subscript𝑆𝑗superscriptsubscriptΨ𝑗𝜏global1superscriptsubscriptΨ𝑗𝜏globalifsubscript𝑗1ℰsubscriptΞ𝑚1subscript𝑠𝑚superscriptsubscriptΨ𝜏local1superscriptsubscriptΨ𝜏localifsubscript𝑗1\displaystyle\Pi_{j}\!=\!\begin{cases}\mathcal{E}(\overline{\Xi}_{j})\Big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{S_{j}\Psi_{j,\tau}^{\mathrm{global}}}}+\frac{1}{\Psi_{j,\tau}^{\mathrm{global}}}\Big{)},&\mathrm{if}\ {|\Im_{j}|}>1,\\ \mathcal{E}(\Xi_{m})\Big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{s_{m}\Psi_{\max,\tau}^{\mathrm{local}}}}+\frac{1}{\Psi_{\max,\tau}^{\mathrm{local}}}\Big{)},&\mathrm{if}\ {|\Im_{j}|}=1.\end{cases} (25)

6) Federation satisfaction function. The federation satisfaction function 𝒮​(Πj)𝒮subscriptΠ𝑗\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j}) measures the satisfaction that the pool ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j} receives in the expected accuracy loss ΠjsubscriptΠ𝑗\Pi_{j}. Generally, the lower the accuracy loss, the higher the federation satisfaction. Besides, it becomes harder to further reduce the accuracy loss when the loss is smaller, indicating that the faster the drop rate of accuracy loss, the higher the obtained federation satisfaction. Thereby, 𝒮​(Πj)𝒮subscriptΠ𝑗\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j}) should satisfy 𝒮​(Πj)≥0𝒮subscriptΠ𝑗0\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j})\geq 0, d​𝒮​(Πj)d​Πj<0d𝒮subscriptΠ𝑗dsubscriptΠ𝑗0\frac{\mathrm{d}\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j})}{\mathrm{d}\Pi_{j}}<0, and d2​𝒮​(Πj)d​Πj2≥0superscriptd2𝒮subscriptΠ𝑗dsuperscriptsubscriptΠ𝑗20\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j})}{\mathrm{d}\Pi_{j}^{2}}\geq 0. A well-suited satisfaction function satisfying these requirements can be the exponential decay function [35] given by

𝒮​(Πj)=γs​exp⁡(−γd⋅Πj),𝒮subscriptΠ𝑗subscript𝛾𝑠⋅subscript𝛾𝑑subscriptΠ𝑗\displaystyle\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j})=\gamma_{s}\exp(-\gamma_{d}\cdot\Pi_{j}), (26)

where γs>0subscript𝛾𝑠0\gamma_{s}>0 is the satisfaction parameter, and γd>0subscript𝛾𝑑0\gamma_{d}>0 is the decay parameter which controls the decay speed. A larger γdsubscript𝛾𝑑\gamma_{d} indicates a faster decay of satisfaction.

Next, we analyze the federation cost in pool formulation.

7) Federation cost function. The miners in pool ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j} need to frequently synchronize the latest global model from the curator. According to [36, 37], the federation cost 𝒞​(ℑj)𝒞subscript𝑗\mathcal{C}(\Im_{j}) can be measured by the communication cost which varies linearly with the federation size |ℑj|subscript𝑗{|\Im_{j}|}. We have

𝒞​(ℑj)={λc​|ℑj|,if​|ℑj|>1,0,if​|ℑj|=1,𝒞subscript𝑗casessubscript𝜆𝑐subscript𝑗ifsubscript𝑗10ifsubscript𝑗1\displaystyle\mathcal{C}(\Im_{j})=\begin{cases}\lambda_{c}{|\Im_{j}|},&\mathrm{if}\ {|\Im_{j}|}>1,\\ 0,&\mathrm{if}\ {|\Im_{j}|}=1,\end{cases} (27)

where λc>0subscript𝜆𝑐0\lambda_{c}>0 is a scaling factor.

Finally, the federation utility of pool ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j} can be obtained as the difference between the federation satisfaction and the federation cost, i.e.,

𝒰​(ℑj)=𝒮​(Πj)−𝒞​(ℑj)𝒰subscript𝑗𝒮subscriptΠ𝑗𝒞subscript𝑗\displaystyle~{}~{}\mathcal{U}(\Im_{j})=\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j})-\mathcal{C}(\Im_{j})
={γs​exp⁡(−γd​ℰ​(Ξ¯j)​(1∑m=1|ℑj|αm​sm​⌊TτtrainDjmax⌋+⌊TτtrainDjmax⌋−1))−λc​|ℑj|,if​|ℑj|>1,γs​exp⁡(−γd​ℰ​(Ξj)​(1sj​Ψmax,τlocal+1Ψmax,τlocal)),if​|ℑj|=1.absentcasessubscript𝛾𝑠subscript𝛾𝑑ℰsubscript¯Ξ𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑗subscript𝛼𝑚subscript𝑠𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑇𝜏trainsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑗superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝜏trainsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑗1otherwisesubscript𝜆𝑐subscript𝑗ifsubscript𝑗1otherwisesubscript𝛾𝑠subscript𝛾𝑑ℰsubscriptΞ𝑗1subscript𝑠𝑗superscriptsubscriptΨ𝜏local1superscriptsubscriptΨ𝜏localifsubscript𝑗1otherwise\displaystyle\!=\!\begin{cases}\gamma_{s}\exp\left(-\gamma_{d}\mathcal{E}(\overline{\Xi}_{j})\Big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{\sum_{m=1}^{|\Im_{j}|}{\alpha_{m}s_{m}}\big{\lfloor}\frac{T_{\tau}^{\mathrm{train}}}{D_{j}^{\max}}\big{\rfloor}}}\!+\!{\Big{\lfloor}\frac{T_{\tau}^{\mathrm{train}}}{D_{j}^{\max}}\Big{\rfloor}}^{\!-\!1}\Big{)}\right)\\ ~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}-\lambda_{c}{|\Im_{j}|},~{}\mathrm{if}\ {|\Im_{j}|}>1,\\ \gamma_{s}\exp\left(-\gamma_{d}\mathcal{E}(\Xi_{j})\Big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{s_{j}\Psi_{\max,\tau}^{\mathrm{local}}}}+\frac{1}{\Psi_{\max,\tau}^{\mathrm{local}}}\Big{)}\right),\mathrm{if}\ {|\Im_{j}|}=1.\end{cases} (28)

Let W​(ℑ)𝑊W(\Im) denote the social welfare of a partition ℑ\Im, i.e., the sum of federation utilities of disjoint pools in a partition ℑ\Im. The target of PF-PoFL is to maximize the social welfare by forming the optimal partition structure ℑ∗superscript\Im^{*}, where the optimization problem for task τ𝜏\tau is formulated as:

𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐦:max⁡W​(ℑ):=∑j=1|ℑ|𝒰​(ℑj).:𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐦assign𝑊superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝒰subscript𝑗\displaystyle\mathbf{Problem:}\,\max W(\Im):=\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{|\Im|}{\mathcal{U}(\Im_{j})}.
s.t.ℑj∩ℑj′=∅,∀j≠j′,∪j=1|ℑ|ℑj=ℳτ.formulae-sequencestformulae-sequencesubscript𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑗′formulae-sequencefor-all𝑗superscript𝑗′superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑗subscriptℳ𝜏\displaystyle\mathrm{s.t.}\ {\Im_{j}}\cap{\Im_{j^{\prime}}}=\emptyset,\forall j\neq j^{\prime},\cup_{j=1}^{{|\Im|}}{\Im_{j}}=\mathcal{M}_{\tau}. (29)

V-B Stable Pool Formation Algorithm

To solve the problem in (V-A), the pooled-mining formation process among miners is modeled as a federation formation game with transferable utility (FFG-TU), where distributed miners (as game players) tend to form various disjoint federations to maximize their individual profits [38].

Definition 2 (FFG-TU game): For each uncompleted FL task τ𝜏\tau, a FFG-TU game for optimized pool structure is defined by a triple (ℳτ,𝒰,ℑ)subscriptℳ𝜏𝒰(\mathcal{M}_{\tau},\mathcal{U},\Im), where the specific formulation is shown as below.

  • •

    Players: The players of the game is the set of miners (i.e., ℳτsubscriptℳ𝜏\mathcal{M}_{\tau}) that participate FL task τ𝜏\tau.

  • •

    Transferable federation utility: 𝒰​(ℑj)𝒰subscript𝑗\mathcal{U}(\Im_{j}) is the federation utility of each federation (or pool) ℑj⊆ℳτsubscript𝑗subscriptℳ𝜏\Im_{j}\subseteq\mathcal{M}_{\tau}, which can be apportioned arbitrarily among the members of ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j}.

  • •

    Pooled structure: A pooled structure (or a federation partition) is defined as the set ℑ={ℑ1,⋯,ℑJ}subscript1⋯subscript𝐽\Im=\{\Im_{1},\cdots,\Im_{J}\} that partitions the miner set ℳτsubscriptℳ𝜏\mathcal{M}_{\tau}. Here, ℑj,j=1,⋯,Jformulae-sequencesubscript𝑗𝑗1⋯𝐽\Im_{j},j=1,\cdots,J are disjoint federations such that ℑj∩ℑj′=∅subscript𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑗′{\Im_{j}}\cap{\Im_{j^{\prime}}}=\emptyset, ∀j≠j′for-all𝑗superscript𝑗′\forall j\neq j^{\prime}, and ∪j=1Jℑj=ℳτsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽subscript𝑗subscriptℳ𝜏\cup_{j=1}^{J}{\Im_{j}}=\mathcal{M}_{\tau}.

  • •

    Strategy: Each miner decides whether to work alone by adopting the solo mining strategy or choose a federation to join to cooperatively train a FL model using the federated mining strategy.

Definition 3 (Switch operation): A switch operation Φl,k​(m)subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘𝑚\Phi_{l,k}(m) is defined as the transfer of miner m𝑚m from the current pool ℑl∈ℑsubscript𝑙\Im_{l}\in\Im to another pool ℑk∈ℑ∪{∅}subscript𝑘\Im_{k}\in\Im\cup\{\emptyset\}, mathematically,

Φl,k​(m):ℑl▷{ℑl−,{m}}​and​{ℑk,{m}}▷ℑk+.:subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘𝑚▷subscript𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑚andsubscript𝑘𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘\displaystyle\Phi_{l,k}(m):\Im_{l}\triangleright\{\Im_{l}^{-},\{m\}\}\ \mathrm{and}\ \{\Im_{k},\{m\}\}\triangleright\Im_{k}^{+}. (30)
Remark 2

The switch operation consists of two successive parts: the split operation (i.e., ℑl▷{ℑl−,{m}}▷subscript𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑚\Im_{l}\triangleright\{\Im_{l}^{-},\{m\}\}) and the merge operation (i.e., {ℑk,{m}}▷ℑk+▷subscript𝑘𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘\{\Im_{k},\{m\}\}\triangleright\Im_{k}^{+}), where ℑl−=ℑl\{m}superscriptsubscript𝑙\subscript𝑙𝑚\Im_{l}^{-}=\Im_{l}\backslash\{m\} and ℑl+=ℑk∪{m}superscriptsubscript𝑙subscript𝑘𝑚\Im_{l}^{+}=\Im_{k}\cup\{m\}. In the case that ℑl={m}subscript𝑙𝑚\Im_{l}=\{m\}, Φl,k​(m)subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘𝑚\Phi_{l,k}(m) means the merge of ℑlsubscript𝑙\Im_{l} with ℑksubscript𝑘\Im_{k}, causing the number of federations decrease by one. In the case that ℑk={∅}subscript𝑘\Im_{k}=\{\emptyset\}, Φl,k​(m)subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘𝑚\Phi_{l,k}(m) means the formation of a new singleton ℑk={m}subscript𝑘𝑚\Im_{k}=\{m\}, causing the number of federations increase by one. In the case that k=l𝑘𝑙k=l, it means miner n𝑛n stays in the current federation and the number of federations remains unchanged.

Definition 4 (Switch gain): The switch gain Ωm​(Φl,k)subscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k}) related to the switch operation Φl,k​(m)subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘𝑚\Phi_{l,k}(m) is defined as:

Ωm​(Φl,k):=vm​(ℑk∪{m})−vm​(ℑl)assignsubscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘subscript𝑣𝑚subscript𝑘𝑚subscript𝑣𝑚subscript𝑙\displaystyle\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k}):=v_{m}(\Im_{k}\cup\{m\})-v_{m}(\Im_{l})
=[𝒰​(ℑk∪{m})−𝒰​(ℑk)]−[𝒰​(ℑl)−𝒰​(ℑl\{m})].absentdelimited-[]𝒰subscript𝑘𝑚𝒰subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝒰subscript𝑙𝒰\subscript𝑙𝑚\displaystyle=[\mathcal{U}(\Im_{k}\cup\{m\})-\mathcal{U}(\Im_{k})]-[\mathcal{U}(\Im_{l})-\mathcal{U}(\Im_{l}\backslash\{m\})]. (31)

Here, vm​(ℑk∪{m})subscript𝑣𝑚subscript𝑘𝑚v_{m}(\Im_{k}\cup\{m\}) and vm​(ℑl)subscript𝑣𝑚subscript𝑙v_{m}(\Im_{l}) mean the extra utility value that miner m𝑚m brings to the pools ℑk∪{m}subscript𝑘𝑚\Im_{k}\cup\{m\} and ℑlsubscript𝑙\Im_{l}, respectively.

Remark 3

Specially, we define Ωm​(Φl,k)=0subscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘0\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})=0 when k=l𝑘𝑙k=l. Besides, when ℑk={∅}subscript𝑘\Im_{k}=\{\emptyset\}, we have Ωm​(Φl,∅)=𝒰​({m})−vm​(ℑl)subscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝒰𝑚subscript𝑣𝑚subscript𝑙\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,\emptyset})=\mathcal{U}(\{m\})-v_{m}(\Im_{l}). The transferable switch gain in the pool switch operation accords with the transferable utility of our proposed federation formation game. Besides, the federation gain of any switch operation only relies on the utilities of involved pools, rather than the manner that federation utilities are shared among their members.

Definition 5 (Preference order): For any miner m∈ℳτ𝑚subscriptℳ𝜏m\in\mathcal{M}_{\tau}, the preference order ⪰succeeds-or-equals\succeq is defined as a complete and transitive binary relation between two switch operations Φl,k​(m)subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘𝑚\Phi_{l,k}(m) and Φl′,k′​(m)subscriptΦsuperscript𝑙′superscript𝑘′𝑚\Phi_{l^{\prime},k^{\prime}}(m) such that:

Φl,k​(m)⪰Φl′,k′​(m)⇔Ωm​(Φl,k)≥Ωm​(Φl′,k′).⇔succeeds-or-equalssubscriptΦ𝑙𝑘𝑚subscriptΦsuperscript𝑙′superscript𝑘′𝑚subscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘subscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦsuperscript𝑙′superscript𝑘′\displaystyle\Phi_{l,k}(m)\succeq\Phi_{l^{\prime},k^{\prime}}(m)\Leftrightarrow\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})\geq\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l^{\prime},k^{\prime}}). (32)

Similarly, for the strict preference order ≻succeeds\succ, we also have Φl,k​(m)≻Φl′,k′​(m)⇔Ωm​(Φl,k)>Ωm​(Φl′,k′)⇔succeedssubscriptΦ𝑙𝑘𝑚subscriptΦsuperscript𝑙′superscript𝑘′𝑚subscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘subscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦsuperscript𝑙′superscript𝑘′\Phi_{l,k}(m)\succ\Phi_{l^{\prime},k^{\prime}}(m)\Leftrightarrow\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})>\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l^{\prime},k^{\prime}}).

As miners can transfer from one federation to another, the federation partition (i.e., ℑ{\Im}) varies with time. The solution of the proposed FFG-TU game is a stable pooled structure ℑ∗superscript\Im^{*}. In general, the stable partition outcome can be attained using exhaustive search methods, where the possible partition iterations increase exponentially with the number of involved miners [37]. In the following, we design a distributed stable pool formation algorithm with low computational complexity in Algorithm 3 to obtain the optimal federation partition strategy of each player (i.e., miner m𝑚m) in the game. The proposed algorithm consists of the following three phases.

Phase 1: Pool initialization (line 3). At the beginning (h=0ℎ0h=0), an initial partition ℑ(0)superscript0{\Im^{(0)}} is generated according to the specific application. For example, the initial partition can be the result of the stable partition outcome for the previously finished FL task.

Phase 2: Switch strategy-making on miner's side (lines 5–8). Given the current federation partition ℑ(h)={ℑ1(h),⋯,ℑJ(h)(h)}superscriptℎsuperscriptsubscript1ℎ⋯superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐽ℎℎ{\Im}^{(h)}=\{\Im_{1}^{(h)},\cdots,\Im_{J^{(h)}}^{(h)}\}, each miner can opt three strategies: (i) stay in the current federation; (ii) split from the current federation and merge with any other non-empty federation; and (iii) split from the current federation and act alone. The first two strategies are federated mining strategies and the last one is the solo mining strategy. To formulate each miner's switch strategy, the switchable candidate pool is first defined as below.

Definition 6 (Switchable candidate pool): For each miner m∈ℑl𝑚subscript𝑙m\in{\Im_{l}}, its switchable candidate pool set is defined as 𝒞mpoolsuperscriptsubscript𝒞𝑚pool\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}, where Ωm​(Φl,k)>0,∀ℑk∈𝒞mpool⊆ℑ∪{∅}formulae-sequencesubscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘0for-allsubscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑚pool\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})>0,\forall\Im_{k}\in\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}\subseteq\Im\cup\{\emptyset\}. In other words, only the pool with positive switch gain can be added into the switchable candidate pool set.

Remark 4

If Ωm​(Φl,k)≤0,∀ℑk∈ℑ∪{∅}formulae-sequencesubscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘0for-allsubscript𝑘\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})\leq 0,\forall\Im_{k}\in\Im\cup\{\emptyset\}, there exists no available federation in ℑ\Im nor the empty set to transfer for the miner m𝑚m (i.e., 𝒞mpool=∅superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑚pool\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}=\emptyset), indicating that the miner intends to stay in the current federation ℑlsubscript𝑙\Im_{l} (i.e., Φl,l​(m)subscriptΦ𝑙𝑙𝑚\Phi_{l,l}(m)). Otherwise, the miner makes its strategy based on the following switch rule.

Definition 7 (Switch rule): Given the switchable candidate pool set 𝒞mpool∪{∅}superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑚pool\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}\cup\{\emptyset\}, each miner m∈ℑl𝑚subscript𝑙m\in{\Im_{l}} sends transfer request to the candidate pool ℑj∗subscriptsuperscript𝑗\Im_{j^{*}} with the largest switch gain, i.e.,

ℑj∗=arg​max⁡Ωm​(Φl,j),m∈ℑl,∀ℑj∈𝒞mpool∪{∅},formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑗argmaxsubscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑗formulae-sequence𝑚subscript𝑙for-allsubscript𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑚pool\displaystyle\Im_{j^{*}}=\operatorname{arg\,max}\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,j}),m\in{\Im_{l}},\forall\Im_{j}\in\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}\cup\{\emptyset\}, (35)

where ℑlsubscript𝑙{\Im_{l}} is the current federation of miner m𝑚m.

Remark 5

In the case arg​max⁡{Ωm​(Φl,j):∀ℑj∈𝒞mpool∪{∅}}={∅}argmax:subscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑗for-allsubscript𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑚pool\operatorname{arg\,max}\big{\{}\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,j})\!:\!\forall\Im_{j}\in\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}\cup\{\emptyset\}\big{\}}\!=\!\{\emptyset\}, it means that the miner m𝑚m prefers the solo mining strategy and will split from the current federation (i.e., Φl,∅​(m)subscriptΦ𝑙𝑚\Phi_{l,\emptyset}(m)). In the other case arg​max⁡{Ωm​(Φl,j):∀ℑj∈𝒞mpool∪{∅}}=ℑj∗argmax:subscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑗for-allsubscript𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑚poolsubscriptsuperscript𝑗\operatorname{arg\,max}\left\{\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,j})\!:\!\forall\Im_{j}\in\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}\cup\{\emptyset\}\right\}=\Im_{j^{*}}, it means that the miner m𝑚m prefers splitting from the current federation ℑlsubscript𝑙\Im_{l} and merging with another federation ℑj∗subscriptsuperscript𝑗\Im_{j^{*}} (i.e., Φl,j∗​(m)subscriptΦ𝑙superscript𝑗𝑚\Phi_{l,j^{*}}(m)).

To summarize, ∀ℑj∈𝒞mpool∪{∅}for-allsubscript𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑚pool\forall\Im_{j}\in\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}\cup\{\emptyset\}, the optimal switch strategy of each miner m∈ℑl𝑚subscript𝑙m\in\Im_{l} can be expressed as

Φl,k∗​(m)={Φl,l​(m),if​𝒞mpool=∅,Φl,∅​(m),if​arg​max⁡Ωm​(Φl,j)={∅},Φl,j∗​(m),if​arg​max⁡Ωm​(Φl,j)=ℑj∗.superscriptsubscriptΦ𝑙𝑘𝑚casessubscriptΦ𝑙𝑙𝑚ifsuperscriptsubscript𝒞𝑚poolsubscriptΦ𝑙𝑚ifargmaxsubscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑗subscriptΦ𝑙superscript𝑗𝑚ifargmaxsubscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑗\displaystyle\Phi_{l,k}^{*}(m)=\begin{cases}\Phi_{l,l}(m),&\mathrm{if}\ \mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}=\emptyset,\\ \Phi_{l,\emptyset}(m),&\mathrm{if}\ \operatorname{arg\,max}\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,j})\!=\!\{\emptyset\},\\ \Phi_{l,j^{*}}(m),&\mathrm{if}\ \operatorname{arg\,max}\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,j})\!=\!\Im_{j^{*}}.\end{cases} (36)

Phase 3: Admission strategy-making on pool's side (lines 9–17). When multiple miners request to join the same pool ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j}, the switch order can affect the federation utilities and the federation formation outcome. To capture the pool's preference for the transfer order, the admission rule is defined as below.

Definition 8 (Admission rule): For a set of candidate miners (i.e., 𝒞jminersuperscriptsubscript𝒞𝑗miner\mathcal{C}_{j}^{\mathrm{miner}}) that send transfer request to the same pool ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j}, only the candidate m∗superscript𝑚m^{*} with the largest switch gain is permitted by the pool ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j}, i.e.,

m∗=arg​max⁡Ωm​(Φl,j),m∈ℑl,∀m∈𝒞jminer,formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑚argmaxsubscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑗formulae-sequence𝑚subscript𝑙for-all𝑚superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑗miner\displaystyle{m^{*}}=\operatorname{arg\,max}\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,j}),m\in{\Im_{l}},\forall m\in\mathcal{C}_{j}^{\mathrm{miner}}, (37)

and other candidate miners in the set 𝒞jminer\{m∗}\superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑗minersuperscript𝑚\mathcal{C}_{j}^{\mathrm{miner}}\backslash\left\{{{m^{*}}}\right\} are rejected.

According to the admission rule, each pool ℑj∈ℑsubscript𝑗\Im_{j}\in\Im accepts the most preferred miner m∗∈ℑl′superscript𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑙′m^{*}\in\Im_{l^{\prime}} (in line 11) and rejects other candidates (in line 12). Correspondingly, the switch operation is performed between two pools ℑj,ℑl′∈ℑsubscript𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑙′\Im_{j},\Im_{l^{\prime}}\in\Im consisting of the split operation (i.e., ℑl′(h)▷{ℑl′(h+1),{m∗}}▷superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑙′ℎsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑙′ℎ1superscript𝑚{\Im_{l^{\prime}}^{(h)}}\triangleright\big{\{}{{\Im_{l^{\prime}}^{(h+1)}},\left\{{{m^{*}}}\right\}}\big{\}}) and the merge operation (i.e., {ℑj(h),{m∗}}▷ℑj(h+1)▷superscriptsubscript𝑗ℎsuperscript𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗ℎ1\big{\{}{{\Im_{j}^{(h)}},\left\{{{m^{*}}}\right\}}\big{\}}\triangleright{\Im_{j}^{(h+1)}}), where ℑl′(h+1)=ℑl′(h)\{m∗}superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑙′ℎ1\superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑙′ℎsuperscript𝑚{\Im_{l^{\prime}}^{(h+1)}}={\Im_{l^{\prime}}^{(h)}}\backslash\left\{{{m^{*}}}\right\} and ℑj(h+1)=ℑj(h)∪{m∗}superscriptsubscript𝑗ℎ1superscriptsubscript𝑗ℎsuperscript𝑚{\Im_{j}^{(h+1)}}={\Im_{j}^{(h)}}\cup\left\{{{m^{*}}}\right\}. Then, the federation structure is updated as ℑ(h)→ℑ(h+1)→superscriptℎsuperscriptℎ1{\Im}^{(h)}\rightarrow{\Im}^{(h+1)} (in line 17).

The above phases 2-3 are repeated until no miner m∈ℑl∗⊆ℳτ𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑙subscriptℳ𝜏m\in\Im_{l}^{*}\subseteq\mathcal{M}_{\tau} in the final pooled structure ℑ∗superscript\Im^{*} intends to execute switch operations to increase the overall gain by transferring to another pool ℑj∗∈ℑ∗∪{∅}superscriptsubscript𝑗superscript\Im_{j}^{*}\in{\Im}^{*}\cup\{\emptyset\} with j≠l𝑗𝑙j\neq l, i.e., Φl,l​(m)⪰Φl,j​(m)succeeds-or-equalssubscriptΦ𝑙𝑙𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑗𝑚\Phi_{l,l}(m)\succeq\Phi_{l,j}(m).

V-C Property Analysis

Given any initial partition ℑ(0)superscript0\Im^{(0)}, the federation formation procedure can be formulated as a sequence of switch operations, i.e.,

{ℑ(0)→⋯→ℑ(h)→⋯→ℑ(H)=ℑ∗},→superscript0⋯→superscriptℎ→⋯→superscript𝐻superscript\displaystyle\{{\Im^{(0)}}\to\cdots\to{\Im^{(h)}}\to\cdots\to{\Im^{(H)}}={\Im}^{*}\}, (38)

where H𝐻H is total number of transformations.

Lemma 1

Any successive transformation of the federation partition, i.e., ℑ(h)→ℑ(h+1),h={0,1,⋯,H−1}formulae-sequence→superscriptℎsuperscriptℎ1ℎ01⋯𝐻1{\Im^{(h)}}\to{\Im^{(h+1)}},h=\{0,1,\cdots,H-1\}, can improve the social welfare for miners in ℳτsubscriptℳ𝜏\mathcal{M}_{\tau}.

Proof:

According to Definitions 6–7, for each switch operation Φl,k​(m)subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘𝑚\Phi_{l,k}(m), it results in a strictly positive gain Ωm​(Φl,k)>0subscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘0\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})>0 for the two involved pools ℑjsubscript𝑗\Im_{j} and ℑksubscript𝑘\Im_{k}, while the utilities of other pools in ℑ\{ℑj,ℑk}\subscript𝑗subscript𝑘\Im\backslash\{\Im_{j},\Im_{k}\} remain unchanged. Let ∑(h)superscriptℎ\sum^{(h)} be the set of permitted switch operations during the transformation ℑ(h)→ℑ(h+1)→superscriptℎsuperscriptℎ1{\Im^{(h)}}\to{\Im^{(h+1)}}. Therefore, we can obtain

W​(ℑ(h+1))=W​(ℑ(h))+∑Φl,k​(m)∈∑(h)Ωm​(Φl,k).𝑊superscriptℎ1𝑊superscriptℎsubscriptsubscriptΦ𝑙𝑘𝑚superscriptℎsubscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘\displaystyle W\big{(}\Im^{(h+1)}\big{)}=W\big{(}\Im^{(h)}\big{)}+\sum_{\Phi_{l,k}(m)\in\sum^{(h)}}{\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})}. (39)

The second term in the right side of (39) means the improved social welfare (i.e., the sum of added switch gains) during ℑ(h)→ℑ(h+1)→superscriptℎsuperscriptℎ1{\Im^{(h)}}\to{\Im^{(h+1)}}. As ∑Φl,k​(m)∈∑(h)Ωm​(Φl,k)>0subscriptsubscriptΦ𝑙𝑘𝑚superscriptℎsubscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑙𝑘0\sum_{\Phi_{l,k}(m)\in\sum^{(h)}}{\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})}>0, we have W​(ℑ(h+1))>W​(ℑ(h))𝑊superscriptℎ1𝑊superscriptℎW(\Im^{(h+1)})>W(\Im^{(h)}). Lemma 1 is proved. ∎

In the following, we first prove the convergence of federation partition transformations in Theorem 3. Then, we prove the Nash-stability, near-optimality, and low computational complexity in Theorems 4, 5, 6, respectively.

Theorem 3

Given an arbitrary initial pooled structure ℑ(0)superscript0\Im^{(0)}, the proposed Algorithm 3 can always converge to a final disjoint federation partition ℑ∗superscript{\Im}^{*} after a finite number of transformations.

Proof:

According to the miner's switch strategy defined in Eq. (36), we can observe that a single switch operation either yields (i) a previously visited partition with a non-cooperative miner (i.e., a singleton) or (ii) an unvisited new partition.

Case (i). When it comes to the partition structure ℑ(h)superscriptℎ\Im^{(h)} where miner m𝑚m forms a singleton, the non-cooperative miner m𝑚m should either join a new federation or decide to remain non-cooperative in the next iteration ℑ(h+1)superscriptℎ1\Im^{(h+1)}.

  • •

    If miner m𝑚m chooses to join a new federation, an unvisited partition without this non-cooperative miner m𝑚m will be formed via the switch operation.

  • •

    If miner m𝑚m chooses to remain non-cooperative, any visited partition will not appear in the transformation of the current partition structure.

Case (ii). When it comes to the partition structure ℑ(h)superscriptℎ\Im^{(h)} where a single switch operation leads to an unvisited partition in the next iteration ℑ(h+1)superscriptℎ1\Im^{(h+1)}, the maximum number of partitions among miners in ℳτsubscriptℳ𝜏\mathcal{M}_{\tau} can be given by the well-known Bell number function, i.e.,

b|ℳτ|=∑m=1|ℳτ|(|ℳτ|−1m)​bm,∀m∈ℳτ&b0=1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑏subscriptℳ𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑚1subscriptℳ𝜏subscriptℳ𝜏1𝑚subscript𝑏𝑚for-all𝑚subscriptℳ𝜏subscript𝑏01\displaystyle{b_{|\mathcal{M}_{\tau}|}}=\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{{|\mathcal{M}_{\tau}|}}{\left(\begin{array}[]{l}{|\mathcal{M}_{\tau}|}\!-\!1\\ ~{}~{}~{}m\end{array}\right)}{b_{m}},\forall m\in\mathcal{M}_{\tau}\ \&\ {b_{0}}=1. (42)

According to Eq. (42), the number of transformations of federation partitions in formula (38) is finite. Thereby, in all cases, the transformation sequence in formula (38) will always terminate and converge to a final partition ℑ∗=ℑ(H)superscriptsuperscript𝐻{\Im}^{*}={\Im^{(H)}}, which is composed of a number of disjoint federations after finite H𝐻H iterations. Theorem 3 is proved. ∎

Definition 9 (Nash-stability): A federation partition ℑ={ℑ1,⋯,ℑJ}subscript1⋯subscript𝐽\Im=\{\Im_{1},\cdots,\Im_{J}\} is Nash-stable if ∀m∈ℳτ,∀ℑj∈ℑ,∀ℑl∈ℑ∪{∅},Ωm​(Φj,l)≤0formulae-sequencefor-all𝑚subscriptℳ𝜏formulae-sequencefor-allsubscript𝑗formulae-sequencefor-allsubscript𝑙subscriptΩ𝑚subscriptΦ𝑗𝑙0\forall m\in\mathcal{M}_{\tau},\forall\Im_{j}\in\Im,\forall\Im_{l}\in\Im\cup\{\emptyset\},\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{j,l})\leq 0.

Remark 6

The Nash-stability implies that, under the Nash-stable partition, any single switch operation will not result in a strictly positive gain. In other words, no miner has incentives to move from its current federation to another one or to deviate and act alone in the Nash-stable partition.

Theorem 4

The final partition ℑ∗superscript{\Im}^{*} from Algorithm 3 is Nash-stable.

Proof:

The Nash-stability of partition ℑ∗superscript{\Im^{*}} is proved by contradiction. Suppose that the final partition ℑ∗superscript{\Im^{*}} resulting from Algorithm 3 is not Nash-stable. As a consequence, there exist a miner m∈ℑj𝑚subscript𝑗m\in\Im_{j} and a federation ℑj′∈ℑ∗∪{∅},j≠j′formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑗′superscript𝑗superscript𝑗′\Im_{j^{\prime}}\in{\Im^{*}}\cup\{\emptyset\},j\neq j^{\prime} such that Φj,j′​(m)⪰Φj,j​(m)succeeds-or-equalssubscriptΦ𝑗superscript𝑗′𝑚subscriptΦ𝑗𝑗𝑚\Phi_{j,j^{\prime}}(m){\succeq}\Phi_{j,j}(m). Under this circumstance, miner m𝑚m will execute the switch operation Φj,j′​(m)subscriptΦ𝑗superscript𝑗′𝑚\Phi_{j,j^{\prime}}(m), which contradicts with the fact that ℑ∗superscript{\Im^{*}} is the final partition result of Algorithm 3. Theorem 4 is proved. ∎

Theorem 5

The final partition outcome from Algorithm 3 attains a near-optimal performance.

Proof:

According to Lemma 1, the consecutive transformation of the federation partition, i.e., ℑ(h)→ℑ(h+1)→superscriptℎsuperscriptℎ1{\Im^{(h)}}\to{\Im^{(h+1)}}, can improve the overall social welfare. Moreover, according to Theorem 3, the overall system welfare derived by Algorithm 3 is convergent after several iterations. Besides, instead of allowing multiple miners to simultaneously transfer to a single pool, the switch operation to a single pool is executed in a greedy manner in our work, where only the miner with the largest positive switch gain is permitted. Thereby, the partition result derived through Algorithm 3 is near-optimal, which is also evaluated using simulations in comparison with the exhaustive optimal solution in Sect. VI-C. ∎

Theorem 6

The computational complexity of the proposed Algorithm 3 is 𝒪​(H⋅J⋅|ℳτ|)𝒪⋅𝐻𝐽subscriptℳ𝜏\mathcal{O}(H\cdot J\cdot{\left|{{\mathcal{M}_{\tau}}}\right|}), where J=|ℑ∗|𝐽superscriptJ=\left|{\Im}^{*}\right| is the number of federations in the Nash-stable partition ℑ∗superscript{\Im}^{*}.

Proof:

The complexity of the distributed pool formation algorithm in Algorithm 3 mainly consists of two parts: (i) the first for-loop for each miner to decide its switch strategy (lines 5-8); and (ii) the second for-loop for each federation to decide its admission strategy (lines 9-15). For the first part, it has a complexity of 𝒪​(H​|ℳτ|​J)𝒪𝐻subscriptℳ𝜏𝐽\mathcal{O}(H{\left|{{\mathcal{M}_{\tau}}}\right|}J). The second part has a complexity of 𝒪​(H​J​|𝒞jminer|)𝒪𝐻𝐽superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑗miner\mathcal{O}(HJ{\left|\mathcal{C}_{j}^{\mathrm{miner}}\right|}). As max⁡{|𝒞jminer|}≤|ℳτ|superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑗minersubscriptℳ𝜏\max\{\left|\mathcal{C}_{j}^{\mathrm{miner}}\right|\}\leq{\left|{{\mathcal{M}_{\tau}}}\right|}, the overall computational complexity yields 𝒪​(H​J​|ℳτ|)𝒪𝐻𝐽subscriptℳ𝜏\mathcal{O}(HJ{\left|{{\mathcal{M}_{\tau}}}\right|}). Theorem 6 is proved. ∎

VI Performance Evaluation

In this section, the simulation setup is first introduced in Sect. VI-A, followed by the numerical results and discussions in Sects. VI-B∼similar-to\simVI-D.

VI-A Simulation Setup

We implement the prototype of PF-PoFL on a private blockchain network based on the open-source Go-Algorand project [39] under both local and distributed settings. For the distributed setting (i.e., setting 1), the prototype is deployed across 20 Azure B8ms virtual machines (VMs), with 8 CPU cores and 32 GB of RAM. The VMs spread across five locations: West US, Canada East, UK South, Korea South, and North Europe. Each VM hosts 5 blockchain miners, and the total number of blockchain miners (i.e., N𝑁N) is 100. For the local setting (i.e., setting 2), the prototype is deployed and tested on a single computer with Intel Core i7-8700 CPU (3.6GHz) and 32GB RAM, where the number of blockchain miners is set as 100.

We use Go 1.17 to create and manage the private multi-node networks, as well as handle all networking and distributed systems aspects. We use the Turing-complete PyTeal [40] to write the smart contract in Python 3.10 and use the compileProgram method to produce the bytecode-based TEAL source code, which can be deployed on the blockchain. Besides, miners in a pool use PyTorch to perform federated mining with UDP to produce SGD updates during training, and our prototype can support any AI model which can be optimized via SGD.

Dataset. We consider two types of FL tasks trained on two typical datasets: one type is the handwritten digits recognition tasks on the MNIST dataset [41]; and another is the image recognition tasks on the CIFAR-10 dataset [42]. MNIST consists of 60,000 training images and 10,000 test images with size of 28×28282828\times 28 in 10 classes. CIFAR-10 contains 60,000 32×32323232\times 32 images evenly divided in 10 classes, with 50,000 training images and 10,000 test samples. For the dataset partition among miners, the non-IID setting is adopted. Specifically, each miner is assigned with z𝑧z classes of 600 training samples for MNIST (resp. 500 training samples for CIFAR-10) and the training samples of different miners can be repeated, where the integer z𝑧z is randomly selected from {1,2,⋯,10}12⋯10\{1,2,\cdots,10\}.

Model. For federated mining within each pool in PF-PoFL, the 3-layer CNN model is adopted for MNIST, while the ResNet18 model is employed for CIFAR-10. The total number of communication rounds is set as Ψj,τglobal=200superscriptsubscriptΨ𝑗𝜏global200\Psi_{j,\tau}^{\mathrm{global}}=200, and the sample ratio is set as λs=0.35subscript𝜆𝑠0.35\lambda_{s}=0.35. For the learning algorithm, the mini-batch SGD with local batch size equal to 50 is adopted for all miners, where the initial learning rate η𝜂\eta is set as 0.01 and declines to 0.001 after 120-th communication round. Besides, the local epoch of miners is set as 1 under the federated mining strategy, while the maximum local epoch Ψmax,τlocalsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝜏local\Psi_{\max,\tau}^{\mathrm{local}} of miners is set as 1000 under the solo mining strategy.

Table I summarizes the datasets and models used in PF-PoFL. For the UDP model, the privacy parameters (σ,ϵ)𝜎italic-ϵ(\sigma,\epsilon) are selected from {(3,5.52),(14,1.06),(24,0.61)}35.52141.06240.61\{(3,5.52),(14,1.06),(24,0.61)\}. Besides, we set δ=1×10−6𝛿1superscript106\delta=1\times 10^{-6}. For the federation formation game model, we set γd=30subscript𝛾𝑑30\gamma_{d}=30, γs=23subscript𝛾𝑠23\gamma_{s}=23, λc=0.01subscript𝜆𝑐0.01\lambda_{c}=0.01. In addition, we set miner's initial credit value as c​r​en0=1𝑐𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑛01cre_{n}^{0}=1 and the credit updates as χ1=2subscript𝜒12\chi_{1}=2, χ2=4subscript𝜒24\chi_{2}=4, and χ3=1subscript𝜒31\chi_{3}=1.

Comparing method. We evaluate the performance of the PF-PoFL in comparison with the PoFL scheme [15]. In PoFL [15], its working relies on a central FL platform, and the fixed mining pool structure is employed for federated mining. PoFL ensures privacy preservation and prevents model plagiarism for trained models using homomorphic encryption (HE)-based label prediction and secure two-party computation (2PC)-based label comparison. As PoFL does not specify the detailed agreement protocol to acquire consensus, to be objective and fair, we implement the conventional Algorand BA protocol [18] for miners in PoFL to reach consensus on a new block. Here, the number of miners is set as N=100𝑁100N=100 and the number of malicious or Byzantine miners is set as f=20𝑓20f=20.

In the following, we first evaluate the blockchain throughput, block latency, and system overhead of our PF-PoFL in Figs. 7–8 and Tables II–III. Next, we analyze the impacts of non-IID, number of miners, and privacy parameters on the federated mining process with UDP in Figs. 9–13. Finally, we analyze the efficiency and stability of the federation formation game approach for optimized pool structure in Figs. 14–15.

VI-B System Throughput and Latency

Fig. 7 shows the throughput (measured by transactions per second (TPS)) and the block latency (i.e., the consensus time for a block from being pending to be confirmed) of the blockchain system in the distributed setting. In the blockchain, the shorter the consensus time, the better the consensus efficiency. Here, the consensus time is mainly determined by the delay in model downloading, model ranking, model verification, block propagation, and voting-based agreement process. In the simulation, the ratio of malicious or Byzantine miners is set to be 20%. From Fig. 7, it can be seen that, when the block height grows from 100 to 200, both the TPS and the block latency of our proposed PF-PoFL consensus mechanism remain relatively stable. Specifically, the throughput mainly varies between [300, 500] TPS, while the block latency changes within [18, 25] seconds, which indicates a relatively stable block packaging frequency of our PF-PoFL consensus mechanism. It can be explained as follows.

In the traditional PoW consensus protocol, all miners compete to solve the same PoW puzzle and the fastest node to solve it earns the block rewards. Distinguished from the PoW protocol, in our PF-PoFL consensus protocol, different mining pools can concurrently train on different FL tasks that are in the training phase; meanwhile, in the current block height, the validators prefer to reach consensus on the most urgent and profitable task from all tasks that are in the testing phase. For example, for a FL task τ𝜏\tau with a high difficulty level, in its training phase, validators will carry out consensus on other tasks that are in the testing phase; until the FL task τ𝜏\tau reaches its testing phase, validators will perform consensus on it if the task τ𝜏\tau is most urgent and profitable in current block height. As such, for FL tasks with different difficulty levels, the relatively stable throughput of the blockchain system can be obtained.

Fig. 8 shows the throughput and the block latency of PF-PoFL in the distributed setting when the block size increases from 0.5 MB to 10 MB. It can be observed that our PF-PoFL system can efficiently handle hundreds of transactions per second and the block latency is below 47 seconds. As seen in Fig. 8, with the increase of block size, the block latency keeps increasing while the blockchain throughput first increases then decreases when the block size is over 8.5 MB. It can be explained as follows. On one hand, the higher block size indicates that more transactions are included within a block, resulting in a higher latency in transaction processing and block propagation. On the other hand, the relatively higher block size means that more transactions to be processed in a new block, which brings a higher TPS. However, the TPS cannot grow with the block size all the time. The reason is when the block size is too large (i.e., over 8.5 MB), the time to verify and broadcast the block can be extended, so that the distributed blockchain cannot be synchronized in time.

Table II shows the time cost of executing model ranking contract in PF-PoFL under the distributed setting. The execution time of model ranking contract mainly consists of two parts: the contract running time (to produce local model ranking result) and the time to reach agreement on the final model ranking result (to be committed on blockchain). Note that in Algorithm 1, each validator can process multiple FL model transactions (including model downloading and evaluation) in parallel to reduce the contract running time. As seen in Table II, the average contract running time of validators is 4.952 seconds and the time to reach agreement is 16.583 seconds, leading to a overall latency of about 21.1 seconds.

Table III compares the time cost of model operations for pools and validators in PoFL and PF-PoFL under both local and distributed settings. As seen in Table III, PoFL involves huge computation cost in model evaluation process (i.e., calculating model performance), especially for pools due to the expensive HE operations. Compared with the PoFL scheme, our PF-PoFL adds the Gaussian noise according to Eqs. (7) and (8) to ensure UDP for miners, and the time cost for pools in this process can be negligible. For model ranking and verification operations performed by validators, PoFL only needs to determine the best model. It indicates that if the model with the best performance is verified as true, there is no need to verify other models. In our PF-PoFL, each validator needs to test and sort all relevant models to determine the financial rewards and credit incentives in the block rewarding contract, causing a longer running time (e.g., 172 microseconds for model ranking and 2.927 seconds for model verification in setting 2) than that in the PoFL (e.g., 51 microseconds for model ranking and 1.296 seconds for model verification in setting 2). Besides, Table III shows that the total consensus time for reaching agreement among validators on a new block is about 9.4 seconds in our PF-PoFL in setting 1 (resp. 21.3 seconds in setting 2), which is faster than that in the PoFL, i.e., 12.2 seconds in setting 1 (resp. 39.8 seconds in setting 2). The reasons are as follows. On one hand, the block proposal in PoFL involves huge storage space for encrypted model parameters in HE and 2PC, resulting in a higher block propagation latency. On the other hand, our credit-based Algorand BA protocol can employ more honest miners in the validator committee and incentivize miners to act legitimately and actively, thereby reducing the voting stages and the delay in reaching an unambiguous agreement.

VI-C Federated Mining with UDP

In this subsection, we evaluate the performance of the federated mining process with UDP on MNIST and CIFAR-10, in comparison with the baseline scheme, by changing the number of miners and values of privacy parameters. In the baseline scheme, the curator in a pool directly delivers the raw global update (instead of the perturbed version) to all miners. Fig. 9 illustrates the relationship between average EMD Ξ¯jsubscript¯Ξ𝑗\overline{\Xi}_{j} and relative accuracy loss ℰ​(Ξ¯j)ℰsubscript¯Ξ𝑗\mathcal{E}(\overline{\Xi}_{j}) in Eq. (25) on CIFAR-10 dataset under non-IID settings. As seen in Fig. 9, the relative accuracy loss first grows slowly and tends to increase fast when Ξ¯j>1.2subscript¯Ξ𝑗1.2\overline{\Xi}_{j}>1.2. Besides, when Ξ¯j=0subscript¯Ξ𝑗0\overline{\Xi}_{j}=0, it corresponds to the IID case and we have ℰ​(Ξ¯j)=1ℰsubscript¯Ξ𝑗1\mathcal{E}(\overline{\Xi}_{j})=1. According to Eq. (22), a higher EMD indicates a higher non-IID degree, and thereby a larger drop on test accuracy.

Figs. 10 and 11 show the evolution of test accuracy on MNIST and CIFAR-10 under different privacy parameters in our UDP noise-adding mechanism, respectively, compared with baseline schemes. In this simulation, the number of participating miners is fixed as 100. As seen in Figs. 10 and 11, the test accuracy of the trained model via federated mining with σ=3𝜎3\sigma=3 UDP noise is very close to the baseline under non-IID, while the accuracies of the trained model with σ=14𝜎14\sigma=14 and σ=24𝜎24\sigma=24 are decreased to a certain degree. It is because a higher σ𝜎\sigma implies a higher privacy preservation level, causing larger perturbations to be added to the global model update in Eq. (8) which eventually deteriorates the model accuracy. Moreover, compared with the IID case, the existence of non-IID results in an accuracy drop to the baseline.

Figs. 12 and 13 show the evolution of test accuracy on MNIST and CIFAR-10 under different pool sizes (i.e., number of miners in a pool), respectively. In this simulation, we set σ=3𝜎3\sigma=3. From Figs. 12 and 13, we can observe that with a larger pool size, the performance of the trained model is improving in terms of both accuracy and stability. The reason is that given the fixed sample ratio, when the number of participating miners in a pool increases, the impact of the added UDP noise to the global update in Eq. (8) can be reduced, resulting in the higher accuracy and stability in training FL models.

VI-D Federation Formation Game

In this subsection, we evaluate the performance of the proposed federation formation game in comparison with the exhaustive optimal scheme, the non-cooperative scheme, and the PoFL scheme [15]. In the exhaustive optimal scheme, the optimal pool structure among miners is derived via the exhaustive searching method in a centralized manner. In the non-cooperative scheme, each miner behaves uncooperatively and applies the solo-mining strategy in completing FL tasks. In PoFL scheme [15], all miners utilize the off-the-shelf fixed pooled-mining structure in PoW-based blockchains for federated mining. Here, the total number of miners is set as N=100𝑁100N=100, where miners perform federated mining on CIFAR-10 using the ResNet18 model under the setting 1.

Fig. 14 compares the social welfare W𝑊W defined in formula (V-A) in four schemes. As shown in Fig. 14, when the number of iterations grows, the social welfare of miner partition in the proposed FFG-TU game gradually converges to a stable value after around 7 iterations. Besides, the proposed FFG-TU game can yield a near-optimal performance, as its performance gap to the exhaustive optimal solution does not exceed 2.1% when h≥7ℎ7h\geq 7. In addition, as seen in Fig. 14, the stable social welfare in our FFG-TU game is greater than that in the non-cooperative scheme and the PoFL scheme, and it brings up to about 67% improvement to the non-cooperative scheme and about 17.6% improvement to the PoFL scheme when h=10ℎ10h=10. The reason is that in the non-cooperative scheme, all miners work alone and each of them forms a singleton in conducting FL tasks, resulting in the lowest social welfare. Besides, as different miners generally have distinct training samples and non-IID degrees under heterogenous FL tasks, the fixed mining pool structure in the PoFL scheme cannot adapt to the varying federated mining environment, resulting in relatively lower social welfare.

Fig. 15 further inspects the evolution of partition structure among miners over time in terms of the number of pools and the number of switch operations. As seen in Figs. 14 and 15, the switch operations at each iteration can improve the social welfare for miners, which accords with Lemma 1. Moreover, as observed in Fig. 15, the proposed pool formation algorithm converges to a final disjoint partition structure after 7 iterations and achieves Nash-stability, which accords with Theorems 3 and 4. Besides, Fig. 15 shows that, the number of switch operations |∑(h)|superscriptℎ|\sum^{(h)}| at each iteration hℎh satisfies |∑(h)|≤|ℑ(h)|+1superscriptℎsuperscriptℎ1|\sum^{(h)}|\leq|\Im^{(h)}|+1, where |ℑ(h)|superscriptℎ|\Im^{(h)}| is the number of pools in current partition ℑ(h)superscriptℎ\Im^{(h)}. The reason is that, according to the switch rule and admission rule in Definitions 7 and 8, each miner can either switch to another pool or form a singleton if it decides to leave the current pool, while each pool only admits the optimal miner greedily at each iteration.

According to the aforementioned results, our PF-PoFL can effectively recycle energy for efficient federated mining and attain stable throughput of the blockchain system, low block latency in reaching consensus, desirable model performance with UDP guarantees, and optimized federated structure with high social welfare.

VII Conclusion

In this paper, we have proposed a novel energy-recycling consensus mechanism named PF-PoFL, where the wasted energy in solving cryptographic puzzles in PoW is reinvested to FL. To implement PF-PoFL in a fully decentralized manner, we utilize the blockchain to host the unfinished tasks, perform model ranking, and enforce financial settlement by devising a novel block structure, a model ranking contract, and a block rewarding contract. PF-PoFL also incorporates credit-based incentives to motivate miners' honest participation and improve consensus efficiency. Furthermore, a user-level privacy-preserving model training algorithm is designed to offer rigorous privacy protection for miners in each pool. In addition, based on the federation formation game, we present an optimized pool formulation algorithm, where miners with diverse characteristics (i.e., training samples, non-IID degree, and network delay) in heterogenous FL tasks can self-organize into a disjoint Nash-stable partition. Simulation results have validated the efficiency and effectiveness of the proposed PF-PoFL mechanism. For the future work, we will further investigate the optimized PF-PoFL consensus mechanism with optimal FL task rewarding, task difficulty adjustment function, and non-reusability guarantees.
